Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Remittance Management During Disaster Recovery

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation research improvement project analyzes the roles of different community's members in the decision-making about remittance allocations during disaster recovery. Human migration flows across borders is matched by financial (remittances) and communication counter-flows that sustain both the migrant at their destination and their families at their origin. Remittances sent by migrants are commonly used to meet basic consumption needs and for investment in education and housing, but they are also a key resource that communities mobilize in the aftermath of natural disasters. While it is generally understood that remittances constitute an important source of household income and contributor to community development projects, particularly during disaster recovery, what is less understood is the role of women in the decision-making about the use of remittances during such recoveries. This project will inform the understandings of how remittance management is organized at the local level, specifically women's roles in decision-making, and has the potential to inform policy to be more attuned to the significance of the role of women in remittance management, especially in post-disaster recovery situations. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this project will provide support to enable a promising doctoral student.

This project advances knowledge on how global migration and finance flows rely upon and rework family networks and local communities. It will do so by answering two central research questions. First, it assesses how a community manages remittances in the context of other financial and resources inputs, especially when stressed due to a natural disaster. Second, it investigates how negotiations over remittances are transforming the lives of women. Specifically, this research project will analyze (1) the precise ways that remittances are managed after a natural disaster; (2) how women participate in remittance management at the household and community level; and (3) how the process of negotiating the use of remittances is transforming the responsibilities, labor, and social involvement of women in communities. The doctoral student will combine a comprehensive household survey with qualitative methods such as archival research, participant observation, and semi-structured interviews in a case study of the post-earthquake recovery in Oaxaca, Mexico. The research will contribute new theoretical insights on the relationship between gender, labor, and citizenship as well as generate new findings on how global migration and remittance flows are mobilized by family networks and local communities in post-disaster situations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant from the National Science Foundation allowed a female early-career researcher to conduct an innovative in-depth study on the roles of women in decision-making about remittance allocations. Specifically, the goal of this research was to examine how a community manages remittances in the context of local politics and other financial resources. Situated in Oaxaca, Mexico, this study provides important insights into the precise ways remittances are managed, how women participate in remittance management at the household and community level, and how the process of negotiating the use of remittances is transforming the responsibilities, labor, and social involvement of women.

The NSF DDRI grant provided the co-PI with the resources to conduct qualitative research between September 2018 and January 2020 in Oaxaca, Mexico. The co-PI carried out archival research, collecting data from numerous sources including the National Population Council, National Institute of Statistics and Geography, National Board of Financial Inclusion, United Nations, and World Bank. In addition, the co-PI conducted participant observation in one community, which included attending meetings, observing casual gatherings, assisting people in daily activities, and monitoring content on the community’s digital and radio spaces. The co-PI also conducted 50 interviews with community members. She worked with two research assistants from the community, and two female graduate students from Oaxaca, trained by the co-PI to serve as a moderators during interviews and transcribers of audio interviews.

Based on this in-depth research, the co-PI uncovered how international institutions and the Mexican government are crafting policy that has a focus on women who receive remittances. With approximately 60% of the Oaxacan population unbanked, the Mexican government has introduced a set of strategies that seek to bring remittances into the formal financial system. By tracing these strategies and the international and national scale, this research reveals how this emerging policy agenda has a gendered component: if women link remittances to financial services, they will become empowered and lift themselves out of poverty. 

This research further demonstrates how international and national policies that seek to leverage remittances for financial inclusion affect people within and beyond Mexico. Since 2006 the United Nations has facilitated policies to increase the impact of remittances on development, empower migrants and their families through financial inclusion and encourage migrant investment and entrepreneurship. Relatedly, since 2013 the Mexican government has overhauled its financial infrastructure and set new goals for financial inclusion. Yet, this research reveals that communities and individual women have differing ideas about the management of remittances and finances. The majority of the women that the co-PI spoke with were engaged in managing the money in their household and in their community, but they did not primarily center their feelings of empowerment on money management. Instead, they placed great importance on the responsibilities they share with other people in their community. These findings highlight the importance of how place-based culture and gender differences are nuanced and deserve close attention. 

This research reveals how migration and remittances influence multiple aspects of women’s lives in Mexico. The co-PI found that women experience changes in their familial and community responsibilities, and they feelings of frustration and empowerment over these changes. Many of the women with that the co-PI spoke with described the work that they do for their families and their communities as being very satisfying, but at the same time, they indicated that they face patriarchal obstacles.

The intellectual merit of this research lies in its approach to the gendered processes of remittance management. By bringing together feminist work on economy, labor and migration, this research illustrates how decisions about spending remittances are negotiated by family networks and local communities. In doing so, this study contributes to scholarship on the changing geographies of remittances by forging linkages between geography and broader interdisciplinary debates across critical development studies, gender studies, and feminist and decolonial methodologies.

The findings from this project are applicable to other countries where large portions of the population are receiving remittances and informs policy-making that is more attuned to the significance of gender relations and women as political actors in remittance management.  This project has generated important knowledge that is useful for undergraduate teaching in courses on Mexico, economic geography, and human migration. Through public presentations in Guatemala and the United States and an online article for an international news website, this study also provides the broader public with a better understanding of the multiple challenges migrants and their families negotiate.
